author: VNExplorer
title: Preliminary water allocation forecasts in southern Alberta below average
text: Water supply levels across the province are low. Since December, the Saint Mary River Irrigation District, the largest irrigation district in North America, has been sending monthly updates on what the season could look like. Last week, the Smriti forecasting showed a preliminary water allocation of eight inches at the farm gate. That’s a pretty severe restriction. On a regular year when we have good water supply, we would normally be setting our allocation in the 1516 inch range. So to be down at 8 inches is basically almost a 50% reduction. Well, a finalized number is set to be released at the annual general meeting on April 3rd. David Westwood says it’s important to inform irrigators early so they can make decisions on the types of crops they want to plant. Doctor Willamine Apples, a senior research chair at the Lethbridge College, says certain crops might be limited this year. You could take some water from a crop that might suffer a little bit more or can take a little bit of a hit like weed and move that onto your potatoes. But yeah, with eight inches, you’re probably not going to grow the same amount of of potatoes and sugar beets that you would otherwise do. Which has some farmers turning to purchasing crop insurance. Have seen some increases in participation after large droughts. 2022 there was an uptick we went from roughly 79% across the province up to about 82% this year. In particular with some of the spring soil moisture conditions and irrigators talking about potential restrictions on the irrigated water, I think it’s very important to take a look at it. And while a drought looms, discussions with the province and other irrigation districts along with municipalities continue to ensure supply for everyone. We’re in the process of drafting some water sharing agreements or commitments amongst ourselves to make sure that everybody has access to water, just probably not as much as they normally do, Westwood says. An agreement could be in place by the end of April. Sarah Jones, Global News.

author: Chinwe Michael
title: Sub-Saharan Africa lost $1.56bn to internet shutdown in 2024
text:
Sub-Saharan African countries lost $1.56 billion to government-induced shutdowns in 2024, according to a new report by Top10vpn, an international VPN review website.
This is 19 percent of the total $7.69 billion that was lost to Internet shutdowns worldwide and a 10 percent decline from $1.74 billion reported in 2023.
According to the report, there were a total of 28 Internet shutdowns across 28 countries. Thirteen of these were African countries — Sudan, Ethiopia, Kenya, Algeria, Guinea, Mauritania, Senegal, Mozambique, Chad, Mauritius, Tanzania, Papua New Guinea, and Equatorial Guinea.
It revealed that Nigeria stood out as one of the few sub-Saharan African countries to avoid internet shutdowns in 2024.
Experts say the absence of an internet shutdown suggests that people in that country have continuous and unrestricted access to the internet, allowing them to communicate, access information, and participate in online activities without disruption imposed by the government.
Sudan is the African country that lost the most — $1.12 billion — to Internet shutdowns. Total Internet shutdowns in the country lasted for more than 12,707 hours or over 529 days.
The Internet shutdown in Sudan is mainly due to a prolonged conflict in the country, which has claimed 13,000 and displaced more than 10 million people.
Read also: Sub-Sahara Africa lost $1.74bn to internet shutdown in 2023
Other African countries like Kenya and Ethiopia shut down the Internet because of protests. Both countries lost $75 million and $211 million to Internet shutdowns, respectively.
Major platforms such as X, TikTok, Signal, Facebook, Instagram, and WhatsApp were restricted, affecting approximately 111.2 million internet users in the country.
“Since late February 2024, authorities in Myanmar once again started blocking access to X. As this was a new restriction. This is also the second year we have included blocks of newer social media platforms, such as TikTok and Telegram,” it said.
Globally, Asia led in terms of internet shutdowns in 2024, losing $4.64 billion over 48,807 hours of disruptions affecting 331.3 million people. Sub-Saharan Africa followed with $1.5 billion in losses spread over 32,938 hours and impacting 111.2 million internet users.
While the global economic impact of internet shutdowns decreased by 16 percent compared to 2024, the duration of shutdowns increased by 12 percent in the same period. The report emphasized the damaging effects of internet shutdowns, both in terms of economic and human costs, and highlighted concerns about citizens resorting to unsafe VPNs to circumvent imposed restrictions.

author: Fernando Martínez
title: Admite que acuchilló a una desconocida en Marín “porque se lo pidió el diablo”
text: Admite que acuchilló a una desconocida en Marín “porque se lo pidió el diablo” Acepta una condena de tres años y medio de prisión, además de indemnizaciones que superan los 23.000 euros El acusado de acuchillar –mientras sufría un brote psicótico– a una mujer que paseaba por la calle en Marín, se declaró autor de los hechos y aceptó una pena de 3 años y medio de prisión, en el juicio celebrado ayer en la Audiencia de Pontevedra. El tribunal condena por ello a A.P.L. como autor de un delito de asesinato en grado de tentativa, unido a otro de lesiones, por las que además de la pena de cárcel debe indemnizar a la víctima. Sobre la motivación del ataque, el hombre relató en su día a la Policía algunas frases incoherentes, cosas como que “el diablo le había dicho que hoy tenía que matar a alguien”. La Policía indicó en su momento que todo hacía indicar que fue un ataque inopinado, que el varón perpetró contra la primera persona que se encontró en la calle y que le podía haber tocado a cualquier otra persona que se encontrase en ese momento en la vía pública. La vista que ayer comenzó en la sección cuarta de la Audiencia Provincial de Pontevedra se suspendió en un primer momento porque la víctima se presentó con acusación particular, que inicialmente no estaba prevista. Tras la suspensión, las partes llegaron a un acuerdo de conformidad, por lo que se retomó la vista para cerrar el acuerdo y dictar sentencia ya en sala. Inicialmente, la Fiscalía pedía para el acusado 8 años de prisión, como autor de un asesinato en grado de tentativa, pero finalmente se aplicó la atenuante de alteración psíquica y la de reparación del daño, dado que el hombre ya ha ingresado la indemnización inicialmente solicitada, haciendo un abono de 13.119 euros. En todo caso la acusación particular pidió, dentro del acuerdo, otra indemnización de 12.000 euros por las secuelas psicológicas y estéticas que sufre la víctima. Tras admitir los hechos y las penas solicitadas, se condena al hombre a 3 años y 6 meses de prisión, al alejamiento de 300 metros de la víctima por un período de 5 años tras cumplir la pena de prisión y a 5 años de libertad vigilada. Deberá indemnizar al Sergas en la cantidad de 8.641 euros, por los gastos sanitarios generados, si bien la Fiscalía no se opuso a que realice este pago de forma fraccionada durante un plazo de 24 meses. Hechos Los hechos sucedieron sobre las 9.30 horas del 13 de febrero de 2023, cuando el procesado se cruzó en la calle Jaime Janer de Marín, en las proximidades del colegio de O Sequelo, con una vecina con la que al parecer no tenía ningún tipo de relación. Según expone el escrito de acusación, con la intención de acabar con la vida de la mujer, de forma sorpresiva, la atacó por la espalda con un cuchillo de 15 centímetros. El hombre le propinó varias cuchilladas en el tórax y el cuello. La mujer gritó pidiendo auxilio y, tratando de repeler la agresión, llegó a caer al suelo, donde el procesado la siguió acuchillando. Finalmente, ella consiguió quitarle el arma y la tiró a una finca próxima, momento que aprovechó el agresor para abandonar el lugar. La mujer fue ingresada entonces en el hospital de Montecelo con graves heridas. Ayer pudo acudir al juicio en la Audiencia Provincial. La víctima: “Solo quiero recuperar mi vida anterior” A las puertas del juzgado en el que se iba a celebrar la vista contra A.P.L., la víctima, una mujer que en el momento del ataque contaba 47 años, apuntaba que “yo solo quiero recuperar mi vida anterior”. La mujer también explicaba que había empezado a sentir miedo de pasear por la calle, algo que nunca antes había sentido, “ni siquiera por las calles más oscuras de Marín”. Asegura que ahora incluso pasea con la cámara de su móvil activada, ante el temor de sufrir un nuevo ataque. Esta mujer permaneció ingresada en el hospital pontevedrés de Montecelo en estado muy grave, como consecuencia de las lesiones sufridas. Tras la agresión, el atacante fue detenido por la Policía Local de Marín, cuyos agentes fueron los primeros en llegar al lugar del suceso. Momentos después, se hizo cargo de la investigación y de la custodia del detenido la Policía Nacional. Fuentes de la Policía Nacional confirmaron aquel día que se había detenido a un varón de unos 50 años como autor de los hechos. Asimismo, explicaban que, inicialmente, no consta que la víctima y el varón se conociesen, sino que todo hace indicar que fue un ataque fortuito y que el hombre decidió atacar a la primera persona que se encontró en la calle. El autor de los hechos ingresó en la misma jornada en los calabozos de la Comisaría de Marín mientras en la zona efectivos de la Policía Judicial y Científica recogían muestras sobre lo sucedido. La mujer ingresó en el hospital con varias lesiones de arma blanca, algunas de ellas de cierta gravedad. author: Matthew Seeman
title: chevron-right
text: {p}Fantastic weather is in the forecast on Martin Luther King Jr Day with temperatures climbing throughout the week... We will wrap up the weekend with a storm moving in on Sunday...{/p}{p}TODAY: If you're heading downtown to the MLK Day Parade, temperatures will be around 50 degrees at 10 am. Expect partly cloudy skies on Monday with high temperatures reaching 58 degrees in Las Vegas. Winds will stay light out of the north up to 10 mph throughout the day.{/p}{p}Air quality is ranked 'good' for most valley neighborhoods with levels 'unhealthy for sensitive groups' in the east valley. Pollen levels are low.{/p}{p}TONIGHT: Skies will be mostly clear this evening with cold valley low temperatures dropping to around 39 degrees.{/p}{p}YOUR 7 DAY: Temperatures will keep climbing throughout the work week with highs in the low to mid 60s as high pressure builds. A storm will move into the West Coast on Wednesday, bringing rain and snow showers to Northern Nevada. Temperatures will max out around 65 degrees on Saturday in Las Vegas, followed by a stronger storm moving into Southern Nevada on Sunday. A slight chance of rain showers will be possible in the valley on Sunday (about 20% chance) with light rain amounts anticipated. Forecast totals will be anything from a trace up to .10\". Mountain snow will be more likely on Sunday but the heaviest snow is forecast for the Sierra Mountains to our west. In between the two storms this week some parts of the Sierra will get up to 30\" of snow from now into the start of NEXT week.{/p}{p}Beyond the 7-day forecast, rain shower chances will linger in Las Vegas Sunday through Monday with highs in the 50s. Conditions appear to clear up by NEXT Tuesday and Wednesday with valley highs rebounding back to the mid 60s under mostly sunny to partly cloudy skies.{/p}{p}Check back for more updates & have a great day!{/p}{p}- Chloe Koast{ }{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}Before Monday's festivities got started, the founder of the Martin Luther King Jr. Day parade got his own surprise.{/p}{p}The{ }NFL and the Las Vegas Super Bowl LVIII Host Committee presented Wendell Williams with a pair of tickets to Super Bowl LVIII.{/p}{p}Host committee members presented Williams with the tickets during a preshow for the parade in downtown Las Vegas.{/p}{p}Williams founded the Dr. Martin Luther King Committee of Las Vegas and the annual Dr. King Parade in 1982.{ }{/p}{p}He was also a member of the Nevada Assembly, becoming the first Black speaker in state history.{br}{/p}{p}Fantastic weather is in the forecast on Martin Luther King Jr Day with temperatures climbing throughout the week... We will wrap up the weekend with a storm moving in on Sunday...{/p}{p}TODAY: If you're heading downtown to the MLK Day Parade, temperatures will be around 50 degrees at 10 am. Expect partly cloudy skies on Monday with high temperatures reaching 58 degrees in Las Vegas. Winds will stay light out of the north up to 10 mph throughout the day.{/p}{p}Air quality is ranked 'good' for most valley neighborhoods with levels 'unhealthy for sensitive groups' in the east valley. Pollen levels are low.{/p}{p}TONIGHT: Skies will be mostly clear this evening with cold valley low temperatures dropping to around 39 degrees.{/p}{p}YOUR 7 DAY: Temperatures will keep climbing throughout the work week with highs in the low to mid 60s as high pressure builds. A storm will move into the West Coast on Wednesday, bringing rain and snow showers to Northern Nevada. Temperatures will max out around 65 degrees on Saturday in Las Vegas, followed by a stronger storm moving into Southern Nevada on Sunday. A slight chance of rain showers will be possible in the valley on Sunday (about 20% chance) with light rain amounts anticipated. Forecast totals will be anything from a trace up to .10\". Mountain snow will be more likely on Sunday but the heaviest snow is forecast for the Sierra Mountains to our west. In between the two storms this week some parts of the Sierra will get up to 30\" of snow from now into the start of NEXT week.{/p}{p}Beyond the 7-day forecast, rain shower chances will linger in Las Vegas Sunday through Monday with highs in the 50s. Conditions appear to clear up by NEXT Tuesday and Wednesday with valley highs rebounding back to the mid 60s under mostly sunny to partly cloudy skies.{/p}{p}Check back for more updates & have a great day!{/p}{p}- Chloe Koast{ }{/p}{p}{br}{/p}{p}Before Monday's festivities got started, the founder of the Martin Luther King Jr. Day parade got his own surprise.{/p}{p}The{ }NFL and the Las Vegas Super Bowl LVIII Host Committee presented Wendell Williams with a pair of tickets to Super Bowl LVIII.{/p}{p}Host committee members presented Williams with the tickets during a preshow for the parade in downtown Las Vegas.{/p}{p}Williams founded the Dr. Martin Luther King Committee of Las Vegas and the annual Dr. King Parade in 1982.{ }{/p}{p}He was also a member of the Nevada Assembly, becoming the first Black speaker in state history.{br}{/p}

author: Amerigo Allegretto
title: Researchers highlight opportunities for diagnostic radiology oral exam
text:
The impending diagnostic radiology oral exam should be welcomed for aspiring radiologists, according to an article published January 5 in Academic Radiology.
A team led by Samantha Pfiffner from Wayne State University in Detroit wrote in its editorial that the oral exam, scheduled to start in 2028, will provide opportunities for a more comprehensive evaluation of radiologists.
“The authors of this manuscript commend the ABR for their tireless pursuit to improve radiology education and their comprehensive and inclusive approach to developing the new exam format,” the Pfiffner team wrote.
The American Board of Radiology (ABR) requires residents to pass two exams to become radiologists. These include the diagnostic radiology qualifying exam and the diagnostic radiology certifying exam. The latter can be taken as early as 12 months after residency.
However, the board is replacing the multiple choice-based certifying exam with an oral exam beginning in 2028. The decision to do so came in 2022 following input gathered from key stakeholders such as radiology organizations, other interested entities, and individuals through online surveys.
Pfiffner and colleagues wrote that the new oral exams would see candidates show competencies that the multiple-choice exam does not assess. These include interpretation and communication skills, critical thinking, real-time clinical judgment, and professionalism.
“In particular, the oral exam format may encourage residents to develop a very particular set of skills during oral discussion of cases in case conferences, skills which may be useful in interactions with referring physicians,” the authors added.
They also suggested that the remote format provides candidates with flexibility in choosing their exam-taking environment, especially for those who require special accommodations.
However, the team also acknowledged that transitioning to the oral exam could pose a challenge. They wrote that the content outline for the exam is not yet available and the first class of residents to take this exam has already started training.
“Of note, the ABR elected to continue administering the [certifying exam] a year after the conclusion of residency training when most examinees are immersed in their subspecialty training, which may not represent the time frame to optimally assess their general radiology skills,” the authors added.
Finally, they noted that performance anxiety and technical issues tied to remote exam-taking could be of concern.
The authors recommended in their editorial that radiology training programs adjust their curricula to prepare residents for exam changes, “given the current lack of resources.” They also wrote residency programs should identify and implement interventions for residents who may be considered at risk for failure.
“Residency programs must adapt to these changes by prioritizing education, reallocating resources, and providing adequate preparation time for residents,” the team concluded. “In addition, identifying struggling residents early and offering interventions may improve the pass rate of this examination.”
The full article can be found
here.

author: marco61l40
title: Why Whittier, CA is the Perfect Place to Buy Your First Home
text:
Buying your first home is one of the most significant milestones in life, and selecting the best location is a crucial part of the process. For these considering the Southern California space, Whittier stands out as a main location for first-time homebuyers. Nestled in Los Angeles County, Whittier combines the charm of a suburban neighborhood with easy access to the bustling city. From affordable real estate options to a tight-knit community, here’s why Whittier is the right place to purchase your first home.
Affordable Housing Market
One of the attractive features of Whittier for first-time buyers is its affordability compared to other parts of Southern California. The common house value in Whittier is significantly lower than that of close by cities like Los Angeles, Pasadena, or even Long Beach. This affordability makes it an appealing alternative for those looking to purchase their first home without breaking the bank.
In addition to lower home costs, Whittier presents a range of housing options, from charming single-family homes to more modern townhouses and condos. This variety makes it easier for buyers to discover a property that suits their budget and lifestyle. Whether or not you’re looking for a fixer-higher with potential or a move-in ready house, Whittier has options for every type of buyer.
Robust Community Really feel
Whittier’s small-town vibe provides a unique sense of community that may be hard to seek out in larger cities. Residents take pride in their city, and the neighborhood feel is evident within the local schools, parks, and community events. For first-time dwellingbuyers, this sense of belonging can make all the difference.
The city’s commitment to community interactment is mirrored in its annual events, such because the Whittier Uptown Association’s Street Faire, the Christmas parade, and outdoor movie nights within the summer. These gatherings foster a sense of connection amongst residents and offer loads of opportunities for newcomers to get involved. This tight-knit environment can be especially interesting for these starting households or looking to build long-term relationships with neighbors.
Glorious Schools and Family-Friendly Atmosphere
For families looking to settle down, Whittier affords highly-rated schools that provide a stable foundation for children’s education. The city is served by the Whittier City School District and the East Whittier City School District, both of which are known for their strong academic performance and commitment to extracurricular programs.
Whittier additionally offers a wealth of parks, playgrounds, and family-friendly amenities, making it an ideal place to raise children. With local spots like the Whittier Narrows Recreation Space and Parnell Park, households can enjoy outdoor activities equivalent to hiking, biking, and picnicking, all within shut proximity to home. This family-oriented environment makes Whittier a wonderful alternative for first-time buyers with children or those planning to start a family in the near future.
Handy Location
While Whittier maintains its suburban charm, its location provides simple access to all the perks of dwelling in Southern California. Situated just 12 miles southeast of downtown Los Angeles, Whittier provides a brief commute to the heart of the city, making it perfect for professionals who work in LA but need to escape the hustle and bustle at the end of the day.
The city can also be well-connected to other parts of Southern California through major freeways such as the 605, 5, and 60, permitting residents to easily access neighboring cities like Anaheim, Santa Fe Springs, and Orange County. This convenient location provides Whittier residents with access to a wide range of job opportunities, entertainment options, and cultural experiences, all while providing a quieter and more relaxed place to live.
Safe and Peaceable Environment
Safety is always a priority for first-time homebuyers, and Whittier constantly ranks as one of many safer cities in Los Angeles County. The city has a relatively low crime rate compared to nearby city areas, making it an attractive option for households, younger professionals, and retirees alike. The peaceable residential streets and well-maintained neighborhoods create a welcoming environment for these seeking a secure place to call home.
Conclusion
Whittier, California, affords a unique blend of affordability, community, comfort, and safety that makes it an ideal location for first-time housebuyers. Whether or not you’re looking for a budget-friendly property, a family-friendly environment, or straightforward access to the greater Los Angeles space, Whittier checks all the boxes. Its charm, strong sense of community, and excellent amenities make it a hidden gem in Southern California’s competitive housing market. When you’re considering shopping for your first dwelling, Whittier should be at the top of your list.

author: @nbcwashington
title: Gunmen take hostages at US company in Turkey – NBC4 Washington
text:
Two gunmen took seven hostages at a factory owned by U.S. company Procter & Gamble in northwest Turkey on Thursday, according to media reports, apparently in protest of the Israel-Hamas war in Gaza .
Turkish media published an image of one of the purported suspects inside the factory, a man wearing what appeared to be a rudimentary explosives belt and holding a handgun.
Private news agency DHA said the suspects entered the main building of the facility in Gebze in the province of Kocaeli, at around 3 p.m. local time and took seven members of the staff hostage.
It claimed the suspects’ actions were to highlight the loss of life in the Palestinian enclave. Some 27,000 have been killed in Israel’s military operation since Oct. 7, according to the Hamas-controlled Health Ministry.
We're making it easier for you to find stories that matter with our new newsletter — The 4Front. Sign up here and get news that is important for you to your inbox.
Ismet Zihni said his wife Suheyla was among the hostages. Speaking from near the factory, he told DHA that he had called her. “She answered ‘We’ve been taken hostage, we’re fine’ and she hung up,” he said.
Police sealed off surrounding roads at the factory and were said to be trying to negotiate with the hostage-takers.
P&G’s head office in Cincinnati confirmed an ongoing incident. A spokesperson said: “The safety of P&G people and our partners is our top priority. Earlier today, we evacuated our Gebze facility and are working with local authorities to resolve an urgent security situation.”

author: laprovence.com
title: OM - CAN : le Sénégal s'impose face au Cameroun, Ismaïla Sarr buteur
text:
CAN : le Sénégal s'impose face au Cameroun, Ismaïla Sarr buteur Par La Provence
Publié il y a 5 heures - Mis à jour il y a 4 heures
L'ailier de 25 ans a inscrit un but.
KENZO TRIBOUILLARD / AFP
Grâce notamment à un but de l'ailier de l'OM, les Lions de la Téranga ont décroché leur qualification pour les huitièmes de finale en battant le Cameroun (3-1).
Ce Sénégal - Cameroun était considéré comme le choc des Olympiens . Et pour cause : Pape Gueye, Iliman Ndiaye et Ismaïla Sarr, joueurs actuels de l'OM, font partie de la sélection des Lions de la Téranga ; tandis que le Cameroun compte dans ses rangs Simon Ngapandouetnbu, mais aussi des anciens pensionnaires du stade Vélodrome comme Frank Zambo Anguissa, Georges-Kevin Nkoudou, Olivier Ntcham et Clinton Njie. Sans parler de Faris Moumbagna, en passe d'être acheté 8 millions d'euros par les dirigeants marseillais au club norvégien du FK Bodo/Glimt. A lire aussi : OM. Qui est Faris Moumbagna, le futur attaquant olympien Faris Moumbagna est entré en jeu Et le moins que l'on puisse dire, c'est que les actuels ou anciens joueurs de l'OM se sont mis en évidence ce vendredi après-midi. Pour le Sénégal, l'ailier Ismaïla Sarr, titulaire lors de cette 2e journée de la coupe d'Afrique des nations, tout comme son coéquipier Pape Gueye, a fait trembler les filets à la 16e minute sur une frappe du droit.
En ce qui concerne le Cameroun, c'est l'éphémère milieu de terrain de l'OM, Olivier Ntcham (2021, 6 matches), qui s'est distingué par une passe décisive sur la réduction du score de Castelletto (83). Car oui, ce sont bien les Lions de la Téranga, désormais qualifiés pour les huitièmes de finale de la CAN, qui se sont imposés (3-1). À noter également l'entrée en jeu de Faris Moumbagna à la 74e minute de jeu. L'attaquant camerounais, en passe de rejoindre l'OM, n'est pas parvenu à se créer de réelles opportunités en fin de match.
En continu 22:31
Rugby - Champions Cup : Toulon dit adieu à la coupe d'Europe
